energy.name: Energy
energy.desc: Charisma, confidence, and the drive to lead. The most universally valued leadership trait.

psychopathy.name: Psychopathy
psychopathy.desc: The dark side of leadership â€” cruelty, manipulation, and abuse of power. A critical distinguishing factor.

organization.name: Organization
organization.desc: Precision, consistency, and performance orientation. Essential for operational excellence.

irritability.name: Irritability
irritability.desc: Hot-tempered, aggressive behavior. Varies significantly across leadership contexts.

intellect.name: Intellect
intellect.desc: Wisdom, rationality, and cognitive sharpness. Universally prized in all leadership contexts.

research.title: The Research
research.subtitle: A Lexical Approach to Leadership Personality
research.whyDesc: Most leadership research starts with theory â€” asking participants to rate leaders on pre-defined scales. The lexical approach goes the other way: it starts with natural language. By asking followers to describe their leaders in their own words, we capture the personality dimensions that actually matter to people, not just the ones researchers assumed would matter.
research.insightBoxText: If you want to know what personality dimensions matter in a leader, don't ask researchers â€” ask followers. The adjectives people naturally reach for when describing their leaders encode centuries of accumulated social knowledge about what leadership actually is.
research.bigFiveDesc: The Big Five personality framework (Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism) was derived from descriptions of people in general. But leaders are not 'people in general.' When followers describe their leaders, two factors emerge that the Big Five simply cannot capture:
research.bigFiveFactor1: Supportiveness â€” a warm, nurturing quality that followers cite as crucial but that Big Five measures as generic Agreeableness
research.bigFiveFactor2: Weakness â€” a factor describing ineffective, passive, or cowardly leaders, absent from all standard frameworks
research.study2Desc: Hebrew-speaking followers generated free descriptions of leaders they had personally known. These descriptions were analyzed, reduced to a list of personality adjectives, and factor-analyzed to reveal the five-factor structure.
research.study4Desc: The factor structure was validated across three organizational contexts â€” Business, Military, and Religious â€” confirming both the universality of the five factors and meaningful sector-specific differences in factor scores.
research.sectorTableFootnote: Mean scores 1â€“5 Â· Source: Keshet (2025), Study 4
research.factorEnergyDesc: Captures leadership presence: charisma, confidence, and daring. The single strongest predictor of perceived leadership effectiveness across all three sectors.
research.factorPsychopathyDesc: The dark triad in leadership context. Items like "cruel," "abusive," and "sadistic" emerged organically from follower reports â€” absent from Big Five but central to the follower experience.
research.factorOrganizationDesc: Methodical, accurate, performance-driven behavior. Reverse-coded items (childish, eccentric, infantile) define the low pole â€” critical for business and military contexts.
research.factorIrritabilityDesc: Hot-tempered, aggressive, and confrontational behavior. Highest in military leaders, lowest in religious â€” context shapes acceptable expression.
research.factorIntellectDesc: Rational, wise, cognitively sharp leadership. Universally prized â€” the only factor with a reverse-coded item (silly) and near-uniform benchmarks across sectors.

about.title: Dr. Noam Keshet
about.subtitle: Leadership Researcher & Organizational Psychologist
about.researchFocusDesc: Dr. Keshet's work sits at the intersection of personality psychology, leadership theory, and organizational behavior. His PhD dissertation introduced a new lexical method for measuring leader personality â€” one grounded in the language followers actually use, not in theoretical constructs.
about.finding1: Five robust factors of leader personality emerge from follower-generated language: Energy, Psychopathy, Organization, Irritability, and Intellect.
about.finding2: These factors are consistent across Business, Military, and Religious leadership contexts.
about.finding3: The Psychopathy factor â€” absent from mainstream leadership frameworks â€” is a critical distinguishing dimension between effective and harmful leadership.
about.finding4: Follower-generated language captures aspects of leadership (Supportiveness, Weakness) that standard psychological tools miss entirely.
about.sectorsDesc: One of the most significant contributions of this research is demonstrating that the same five personality dimensions appear across dramatically different organizational cultures â€” from corporate boardrooms to military units to religious communities.
about.assessmentCtaDesc: Rate a leader you know on the 50-item instrument and see how they compare to validated benchmarks.
about.citationPre: Keshet, N. S., Oreg, S., Berson, Y., Hoogeboom, M. A., & de Vries, R. E. (2026). Basic dimensions of leader personality: a lexical study in Hebrew.
about.contactDesc: Interested in applying this research to your organization, speaking engagements, or academic collaboration?

assessment.title: Leadership Personality Assessment
assessment.subtitle: Complete the assessment to generate a leadership personality profile.
assessment.roleSubtitle: Tell us about your role so we can personalize the assessment for you.
assessment.leaderCardDesc: Rate yourself and discover your own leadership personality profile.
assessment.followerCardDesc: Rate your direct supervisor and discover their leadership personality profile.
assessment.instructionsLeader: For each adjective below, rate how accurately it describes YOU as a leader (1 = not at all, 5 = extremely).
assessment.instructionsFollower: For each adjective below, rate how accurately it describes YOUR DIRECT SUPERVISOR (1 = not at all, 5 = extremely).
assessment.genderSubtitle: This helps us personalize the assessment language.
assessment.leaderGenderSubtitle: This helps us refer to your supervisor correctly.
assessment.demographicsSubtitle: Your answers help improve the research. All fields are optional.

results.leaderSubtitle: How your scores compare to real-world business leader benchmarks.
results.followerSubtitle: Your supervisor's leadership personality based on your ratings.
results.profileVizDesc: Blue = your score Â· Red dashed = {sector} sector benchmark
results.followerProfileVizDesc: Seven-factor profile â€” follower ratings of supervisor
results.noData: No assessment data found. Please complete the assessment first.
results.interpretDesc: Scores are means on a 1â€“5 scale. Higher scores indicate stronger presence of that trait. For Psychopathy and Irritability, scores significantly above benchmark indicate a concern worth investigating.
results.followerInterpretDesc: Scores are means on a 1â€“5 scale. Supportiveness and Weakness emerged uniquely in follower ratings; no population benchmarks exist for these two dimensions. For the five shared factors, scores are compared to business leader self-reports (Study 4).
results.disclaimerText: This assessment is a research-based educational tool intended for self-reflection and professional development. Results reflect self-reported perceptions and should not be used as the sole basis for employment decisions, clinical evaluation, or organizational screening.
